title: 104_hr2727
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" aims to ensure that Federal regulations are only enacted by Congress as outlined in Article I of the Constitution, preventing delegation of regulatory power to unelected officials in the executive branch. The "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" aims to end the practice of Congress delegating its regulatory responsibility to unelected officials in the executive branch. It requires regulations proposed by executive agencies to be approved by Congress, promoting a more democratic and accountable process. SEC. 3 of the "Congressional Responsibility Act of 1995" states that regulations cannot take effect before being included in a bill approved by Congress. Agencies must submit a report to Congress with the text and explanation of proposed regulations. SEC. 4. EXPEDITED CONGRESSIONAL PROCEDURES FOR AGENCY REGULATIONS. The bill introduced by the Majority Leader of each House of Congress must solely contain the text of the regulation submitted by an agency. If the bill is not introduced, any Member of that House may introduce it. The term "bill" refers to a legislative document that approves agency regulations to have the force of law. The term "bill" in this section refers to a legislative document approving agency regulations to have the force of law. Such bills are not referred to a committee and can be considered by any Member of the respective House the day after announcing their intention to do so. A Member of the House can move to proceed to consider a bill the day after announcing their intention. All points of order against the bill are waived, and the motion is privileged and not debatable. It cannot be amended, postponed, or superseded by other business. The motion to proceed to consider a bill is privileged in the Senate, not debatable, and not subject to amendment or postponement. If agreed to, the respective House must immediately proceed to consider the bill without interruption, and it remains unfinished business until disposed of. Debate on the bill and all related motions is limited to one hour, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Amendments are not allowed, but a motion to further limit debate is permitted. Postponement, consideration of other business, or recommitting the bill motions are not allowed. Reconsideration of the vote is also not permitted. Final passage of a bill described in subsection (b) must be voted on in a House of Congress within a specified timeframe. Appeals from the Chair's decisions on Senate or House regulations regarding the bill's procedure are decided without debate. Final passage of a bill must be voted on in a House of Congress within 60 days of its introduction. A motion to suspend certain procedures can be passed by a majority vote. If the other House has already acted on the bill, specific treatment applies. Upon passage of a motion by a majority vote, a bill will be considered in the same manner as other bills. If the other House has already received a bill with the same text, it will not be referred to a committee and can only be considered for final passage. Upon passage of a motion by a majority vote, a bill will be considered in the same manner as other bills. If the other House has already received a bill with the same text, it will not be referred to a committee and can only be considered for final passage. The procedure for the bill in the receiving House will be the same as if no bill had been received, but the final vote will be on the bill from the other House. Upon disposition of the bill received from the other House, it shall no longer be in order to consider the bill that originated in the receiving House. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "agency" and "regulation" are defined in accordance with specific sections of the United States Code. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE: This Act applies to agency regulations made after its enactment. SEC. 7. JUDICIAL REVIEW: Regulations in bills from this Act are not considered agency actions for judicial review under title 5, United States Code.
